question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

### Answer:
response:
Given the instructions and the logical operations we can use, here are the symbolized propositions according to the given rule:

For (1): Blue and yellow are both common colors.
- This corresponds to a logical "and" operation between p1 and p2.
- Symbolized as: p1&p2.

For (2): Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
- This corresponds to a logical "or" operation between p3 and p4.
- Symbolized as: p3||p4.

For (3): Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.
- This proposition can be symbolized using the logical "and" and "or" operations, along with the "not" operation. We need to express the condition where \sqrt{3} is irrational and 5 is not, or 5 is irrational and \sqrt{3} is not.
- Symbolized as: (p3&~p4)||(~p3&p4).

Thus, the final answers formatted according to the specified notation are:

[[p1&p2];[p3||p4];[(p3&~p4)||(~p3&p4)]]

### Question:
Given:
p1: 4 is even.
p2: 5 is odd.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd.
(2) If 4 is even, then 5 is even.
(3) Only 4 being even makes 5 even.
(4) 4 is even if and only if 5 is odd.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.

### Answer:
response:
Given the propositions:
- p1: 4 is even.
- p2: 5 is odd.

We symbolize the given propositions using the defined logic rule:
1. "Only if 4 is even, 5 is odd." can be read as "if 5 is odd, then 4 is even," which is represented as p2=::>p1.
2. "If 4 is even, then 5 is even." - since we are given p2 for "5 is odd," the proposition "5 is even" is the negation of p2, represented as p1=::>~p2.
3. "Only 4 being even makes 5 even." - this states that 5 being even is exclusively dependent on 4 being even, so similarly to the second proposition, it can be represented as p1=::>~p2.
4. "4 is even if and only if 5 is odd." can be represented directly as p1=p2.

Therefore, the answers are formatted as:
[[p2=::>p1];[p1=::>~p2];[p1=::>~p2];[p1=p2]].

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formulas.
(1) ~(p1&p2&~p3)
(2) (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)
The answer format  is [[T:...;F:...];[T:...;F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[T:✓|✓|✓;F:x|x|x];[T:x|x|x,x|x|✓;F:✓|✓|✓]]

### Answer:
response:
To determine the truth values (T) and falsity values (F) for the given formulas, we need to analyze the conditions under which each formula evaluates to true or false, according to the logic rules provided.

### Formula 1: ~(p1&p2&~p3)

We need to find the assignments of p1, p2, and p3 for which the formula evaluates to true (T) and false (F). 

#### True Assignments:
The formula will be true if `p1&p2&~p3` is false. Since `~p3` is false when p3 is true, the formula evaluates to true if any of `p1`, `p2`, or `p3` are false (since `p1&p2&~p3` involves all being true to make it false).

- p1 = false (x): The formula will be true regardless of the values of p2 and p3.
- p2 = false (x): The formula will be true regardless of the values of p1 and p3.
- p3 = true (✓): The formula will be true regardless of the values of p1 and p2, but more importantly, it invalidates `~p3`.

#### False Assignments:
The formula will be false if `p1&p2&~p3` is true. For this to be true, `p1` and `p2` must be true (✓) and `p3` must be false (x).

Therefore,
- False when p1 = true (✓), p2 = true (✓), and p3 = false (x)

### Formula 2: (~p1&p2)=::>(p1=p3)

To evaluate this formula, we must consider when the implication is true and false.

#### True Assignments:
The implication will be true if `~p1&p2` is false or if `(p1=p3)` is true.

- `~p1&p2` is false when p1 is true (✓) or p2 is false (x), making the whole implication true.
- If `~p1&p2` is true (which happens only when p1 is false (x) and p2 is true (✓)), then for the whole formula to be true, `(p1=p3)` must be true, which means p3 must be false (x) if p1 is false.

- p1 = true (✓): The implication is true regardless of the values of p2 and p3.
- p2 = false (x): The implication is true regardless of the values of p1 and p3.
- p1 = false (x), p2 = true (✓), and p3 = false (x)

#### False Assignments:
The implication will be false if `~p1&p2` is true (p1 = false (x) and p2 = true (✓)) but `(p1=p3)` is false (meaning p1 and p3 have different values).

- p1 = false (x), p2 = true (✓), and p3 = true (✓)

### Final Answer in Required Format:

[[T:x|x|x,x|x|✓,✓|x|x,✓|x|✓;F:✓|✓|x];[T:✓|x|x,✓|x|✓,x|✓|x,x|x|x,x|✓|✓;F:x|✓|✓]]

(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3

### Question:
Find the falsity values of the following formulas:
(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3
(2)(~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
(3)(p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
The answer format is [[F:...];[F:...];[F:...]].If there are multiple values in F, they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[F:x|x|x];[F:✓|✓|✓];[F:x|x|x,✓|✓|✓]]

### Answer:
response:
To find the falsity values (the values that make these formulas false) of the given formulas, we'll consider all possibilities and determine under which assignments each formula becomes false, adhering to the given logical rules.

(1) Formula: ~(~p1&p2)||~p3  
For this formula to be false, both parts of the OR operation must be false:  
- ~p1&p2 must be true.  
- ~p3 must be false, which means p3 must be true.
In the case of ~p1&p2 being true,  
- ~p1 is true while p2 can be true or false. To meet this, p1 must be false.  
With p3 determined to be true, the falsity assignment is for p1 being false and p3 being true (regardless of p2's status, p2 remains flexible).

Therefore, the falsity for the given formula is when: F is x|✓|✓ for any value of p2.

So for this formula: [F:x|✓|✓]

(2) Formula: (~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)  
For this formula to be false, at least one of its AND components must be false.
- (~p2||p3) is false, which implies both p2 is true and p3 is false.
- (p1=::>p2) is false, which implies p1 is true and p2 is false.

Because the conditions from the components conflict (in the first, p2 must be true, and in the second, p2 must be false), there are no combinations where both conditions can be met simultaneously. Hence, there are no true assignments for the falsity part.

So for this formula: []

(3) Formula: (p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
- (p1=::>p2) is false, which implies p1 is true and p2 is false.
- ~(p1&p3)||p1 is false
    - To make ~(p1&p3) false, then (p1&p3) must be true.
    - To make (p1&p3) true, both p1 and p3 must be true.
Since p1 must be true and p2 must be false for the first part to be false, and p1 and p3 must both be true for the second part to be false.

Therefore, the falsity for the given formula is when: F is ✓|x|✓.

So for this formula: [F:✓|x|✓]

Combining all the findings:

[[F:x|✓|✓];[];[F:✓|x|✓]]

### Question:
Please determine the level of the formula (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1). 
The answer should be given as a single letter from A to Z, or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1).The answer format should be like [[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine the level of the formula (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1), let's break it down into components and analyze the structure step by step.

1. **Identify the Logical Connectives and Their Priorities:** 
    - The formula contains multiple logical connectives: not (~), and (&), or (||), if...then (=::>), and not again (~).
    - According to the priority of logical connectives (highest to lowest: ~, &, ||, =::>, =), operations without parentheses are performed in this order.

2. **Break Down the Formula:**
    - Consider the left part of the formula: (~(p1=::>~p2)).
        - The innermost formula is (p1=::>~p2), which is at Level B (B1).
        - Applying not on this, we get ~(p1=::>~p2), which is at Level C (C1), because it involves nesting not (~) on top of B1.
    - Now consider the right part of the formula: ((p3||p4)=~p1).
        - The inner parts (p3||p4) and ~p1 are both at Level B (B2 and B3).
        - Joining them with =, we elevate to Level C (C2), as C2 involves joining two Level B propositions.
    
3. **Combine the Components:**
    - Joining both parts of the formula with & (Resulting formula: (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1)).
    - The formula now combines a C1 rank formula with a C2 rank formula using the AND operator.
    - Since it involves nesting a level C formula within another, resulting in an even deeper level of nesting, this structure typically goes beyond Level Z. Given these nested conditions, this formula fits into the Z+n category, where n describes how much beyond Z the complexity goes. Here, the increase in complexity warrants a classification beyond Z, leading us to determine it's a Z+1 due to the layered combination of C-level formulas joined by an outer operator.

Therefore, the level of the formula (~(p1=::>~p2))&((p3||p4)=~p1) is [[Z+1]].

### Question:

(1)~(p1=::>p2)&p2
(2) (p1&p3)=(~p1&~p2)

Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.

### Answer:
response:
To determine whether each formula is a Truth Formula, Falsehood Formula, or Neither, we can analyze each formula step-by-step based on their truth assignments and the logical rules given.

### Formula 1: ~(p1=::>p2) & p2

Let's break down this formula and consider its truth values under different assignments.

- The part "p1=::>p2" is True if p1 is False (F) or p2 is True (T). It is False if p1 is True (T) and p2 is False (F).
- Therefore, "~(p1=::>p2)" would be True if p1 is True and p2 is False, and False otherwise.
- Then, combining with "p2", the formula would be:
  - False when p1 is True and p2 is False (because "(~(T=::>F)) & F" equals "F & F" which is F).
  - False when p1 is False and p2 is False (because "(~(F=::>F)) & F" equals "F & F" which is F).
  - True when p1 is False and p2 is True (because "(~(F=::>T)) & T" equals "F & T" which is F).
  - False when p1 is True and p2 is True (because "(~(T=::>T)) & T" equals "F & T" which is F).

Based on this analysis, the formula is not true under all assignments and not false under all assignments. So it is Neither.

### Formula 2: (p1 & p3) = (~p1 & ~p2)

Let's break down this formula and consider its truth values under different assignments.

- The part "(p1 & p3)" is True if and only if both p1 and p3 are True. It is False otherwise.
- The part "(~p1 & ~p2)" is True if and only if both p1 and p2 are False. It is False otherwise.
- Therefore, we need to check if the conditions for truth of "(p1 & p3)" match the conditions for truth of "(~p1 & ~p2)". They clearly don't match under any assignment because the conditions for both being True or False require opposite states of p1.

Given the contradictory requirements to make both parts of the equivalence true or false under the same conditions, it's clear this formula doesn't hold true for any assignment neither does it hold false for all assignments under every possible state of truth for p1, p2, and p3.

Based on this, the formula should be classified as Neither.

Thus, the answers are:

[[C];[C]]

### Question:
Given that (p1=::>(p1||p2))&((p1&p2)=::>p1) is a Truth Formula, determine the type of the following formulas:
(1) p1=::>(p1||p2)
(2) (p1&p2)=::>p1

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

Provide the answer as a single letter.
Separate the answers between each sub-question with ;.
Eventually the entire answer should be formatted like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To solve this problem, we need to analyze the given formula (p1=::>(p1||p2))&((p1&p2)=::>p1) and each of its components individually to determine if they are truth formulas.

First, let's break down the given formula into its two parts as indicated:

1. (p1=::>(p1||p2)) - This is a compound proposition with the ‘if, then’ connective.
2. ((p1&p2)=::>p1) - This is another compound proposition with the ‘if, then’ connective.

### Examining each part:

#### (p1=::>(p1||p2))
We must check the truth value under all possible assignments of p1 and p2.
- If p1 is true (✓):
    - (✓=::>(✓||p2)) is true no matter what the value of p2 is, since the right-hand side will also be true.
    - Thus, this part is always true when p1 is not false.
- If p1 is false (x):
    - (x=::>(x||p2)) is true if p2 is false, but this condition automatically holds because (x||p2) will not make "if false, then false" false.
- Therefore, this part (p1=::>(p1||p2)) is always true, making it a **Truth Formula**.

#### ((p1&p2)=::>p1)
This is another compound proposition.
- If p1 is true (✓):
    - (✓&p2)=::>✓ is true if either p2 is true or false. That's because "if ✓ and ✓, then ✓" is true, and "if ✓ and x, then ✓" is also true.
- If p1 is false (x):
    - (x&p2)=::>x holds true because "if false, then anything" is the definition of an ‘if, then’ where the condition (p1&p2) can never be true if p1 is false.
- Therefore, this part ((p1&p2)=::>p1) is likewise always true, making it a **Truth Formula** as well.

So:
- (1) p1=::>(p1||p2) is a Truth Formula.
- (2) (p1&p2)=::>p1 is a Truth Formula.

The answer should inherently be [[A];[A]].

(2) (p1=::>(p1||p2))||(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)

### Answer:
response:
Given the properties of the formulas provided:

- (p1=::>(p1||p2)) is a Truth Formula. This means that the compound proposition "if p1, then (p1 or p2)" is always true.
- ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is a Falsehood Formula. This means that "not (if p1 then p2) and p2" is always false.

Let's analyze the two formulas given.

(1) (p1=::>(p1||p2))&(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)

This formula consists of the conjunction of two formulas: (i) (p1=::>(p1||p2)) and (ii) ~(p1=::>p2)&p2.

- (p1=::>(p1||p2)) is always true.
- ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is always false.

A conjunction is true only if both parts of the conjunction are true. However, in this case, the second part, ~(p1=::>p2)&p2, is always false. Therefore, the whole conjunction cannot be true—it’s a Falsehood Formula.

(2) (p1=::>(p1||p2))||(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)

This formula consists of the disjunction of two formulas: (i) (p1=::>(p1||p2)) and (ii) ~(p1=::>p2)&p2.

- (p1=::>(p1||p2)) is always true, which means the disjunction will be true regardless of the second part.
- The value of ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 in this case does not affect the whole formula because the disjunction can be true with just one true part.

Therefore, the second formula is a Truth Formula.

[[B];[A]]

title: Equivalence Calculus
rule_content:
1. Propositional Symbolization Rules:
    - Equivalence is represented by `::=::`
    - Negation is represented by `!`
    - Or is represented by `|`
    - And is represented by `&`
    - Implication is represented by `>`
    - Equivalence is represented by `=`
    - NAND is represented by `⇑`
    - NOR is represented by `⇓`
2. Basic Equivalences:
    (1) A ::=:: !!A
    (2) A ::=:: A | A, A ::=:: A & A
    (3) A | B ::=:: B | A, A & B ::=:: B & A

### Answer:
response:
To determine if the expressions \((p>q)>r\) and \(p>(q>r)\) are equivalent, we need to utilize the given logical equivalences and symbolization rules.

1. Convert the implications into the form that uses `|` and `!`:
   - Implication \(A > B\) is equivalent to `!A | B` based on the rule given.
   - Therefore, the first expression \((p>q)>r\) is equivalent to `!(p>q) | r`.

2. Apply the rule \(A > B ::=:: !A | B\) to `!(p>q) | r`:
   - \((p > q) ::=:: !p | q\).
   - So, `!(p>q)` is `!!(p>q)` and `p>q ::=:: !p | q`, which becomes `!(<!p | q)`.

3. Simplify `!(<!p | q)` using the double negation rule \(A ::=:: !!A\):
   - `!(<!p | q)` is equivalent to `\(\neg(\neg(!p | q))\)` which simplifies to `!(p & !q)` using De Morgan's Law (!(\(A\) | \(B\)) ::=:: !A & !B).

4. Therefore, `!(p & !q) | r` is further simplified to `(!p | !!q) | r` and then to `(!p | q) | r`.

5. We'll now do the same for the second expression \(p>(q>r)\) which is equivalent to `p> (!q | r)` following the same conversion rule.
   - This implies `!p | (q>r)` or `!p | ((!q | r))`.
   - Further simplification gives us `!p | (!q | r)`.

6. Now we simplify both expressions further and compare:
   - The first expression `(!p | q) | r`.
   - The second expression `!p | (!q | r)`.

Applying commutative and associative properties:
   - `(!p | q) | r ::=:: !p | q | r` (since `|` is associative and commutative).
   - `!p | (!q | r) ::=:: !p | !q | r`.

Comparing `!p | q | r` and `!p | !q | r`, we can see they are not the same because the second part does not match. Therefore, the original expressions \((p>q)>r\) and \(p>(q>r)\) are not equivalent.

Thus, the answer is [[B]].

### Question:

(1) !(p>(p|q))&r
(2) p&(((p|q)&!p)>q)
Provide your answers as logical expressions formatted as [[];[]].

### Answer:
response:
To solve the given expressions using the specified logical equivalence rules, we must first simplify each expression.

### Expression (1) Simplification

The given expression is:
\[ !(p > (p | q)) & r \]

Using logical equivalence (10), rewrite the implication:
\[ !(p > (p | q)) & r ::=:: !( !p | (p | q)) & r \]

Using De Morgan’s Law (6) on the negated disjunction:
\[ !( !p | (p | q)) ::=:: !!p & !(p | q) \]

Apply the double negation rule (1):
\[ !!p ::=:: p \]

Thus, we have:
\[ !( !p | (p | q)) ::=:: p & !(p | q) \]

Using De Morgan's Law (6) again:
\[ !(p | q) ::=:: !p & !q \]

So, the expression now looks like this:
\[ (p & (!p & !q)) & r \]

Using the distributive property (5):
\[ (p & (!p & !q)) ::=:: ((p & !p) & !q) \]

Since \((p & !p)\) is a contradiction and according to (9) represents \(0\):
\[ ((p & !p) & !q) ::=:: ( 0 & !q) ::=:: 0 \]

Thus:
\[ (p & (!p & !q)) & r ::=:: 0 & r \]

By the truth table of AND with a contradiction:
\[ 0 & r ::=:: 0 \]

The simplest result for the first expression is:
\[ 0 \]

### Expression (2) Simplification

The given expression is:
\[ p & (((p | q) & !p) > q) \]

First, simplify the implication using (10):
\[ p & (((p | q) & !p) > q) ::=:: p & (!((p | q) & !p) | q) \]

Now, apply De Morgan's Law (6):
\[ !((p | q) & !p) ::=:: !(p | q) | !!p \]

Using rule (1) for double negation:
\[ !!p ::=:: p \]

Thus:
\[ !(p | q) | !!p ::=:: !(p | q) | p \]

Again, applying De Morgan's Law (6):
\[ !(p | q) ::=:: !p & !q \]

So, we have:
\[ !(p | q) | p ::=:: (!p & !q) | p \]

Using distributivity (5):
\[ (!p & !q) | p ::=:: ((!p | p) & (!q | p)) \]

Since \(!p | p\) is a tautology by rule (8), representing \(1\):
\[ (!p | p) ::=:: 1 \]

Thus:
\[ (1 & (!q | p)) ::=:: !q | p \]

The expression now looks like this:
\[ p & (!q | p) \]

Using distributivity (5) yet again:
\[ p & (!q | p) ::=:: (p & !q) | (p & p) \]

From rule (2), we have:
\[ p & p ::=:: p \]

So, we get:
\[ (p & !q) | p ::=:: p & !q | p \]

Using (7), we can simplify:
\[ p & !q | p ::=:: p \]

Therefore, the simplest result for the second expression is:
\[ p \]

### Final Answer

So, the simplest results for the given expressions are:
\[ [0; p] \]

### Question:

The answer to each sub-question is a letter of the alphabet, and answers to different sub-questions are separated by ;.The answer format should be like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
To answer the question, we need to individually check if the given equivalences are valid according to the provided logical rules.

### Checking (1) p ::=:: (p&q)|(p&!q)

1. Let's start with the right side of (1): (p&q)|(p&!q).
2. We can use the distributive property (5) of logical expressions to factor out p: (p&q)|(p&!q) ::=:: p&(q|!q).
3. According to the Law of Excluded Middle (8), q|!q is always true (1), so the expression simplifies to: p&1.
4. From the identity of AND with a true statement, we know that p&1 is logically equivalent to p itself.
5. Therefore, p ::=:: (p&q)|(p&!q) is a valid equivalence according to the given rules.

### Checking (2) (p&!q)|(!p&q) ::=:: (p|q)&(!(p|q))

1. Let's examine the left side of (2): (p&!q)|(!p&q).
2. This expression can be translated as 'p is true and q is false, or p is false and q is true', which is the definition of the XOR (exclusive OR), but since XOR is not directly supported, and the target side of the equivalence involves only AND, OR, and negation, we proceed further.
3. Let's look at the right side of (2): (p|q)&(!(p|q)).
4. According to (6), !(p|q) is equivalent to !p&!q, so we have (p|q)&(!p&!q).
5. However, this means that the expression p|q must be true and false at the same time (!p&!q), which is a contradiction (9).
6. Therefore, (p|q)&(!(p|q)) will always be logically false (0).
7. For the initial expression (p&!q)|(!p&q) to be always false, both p&!q and !p&q must be false, but this cannot be determined just from the form of the expression without specific values of p and q.

### Question:
According to the 16 Basic Equivalences, is the equivalence below valid? A. Yes B. No
(1) ((p>q)&(p>r))::=::(p>(q|r))
(2) !(p=q)::=::(p|q)&!(p&q)
The answer to each sub-question is a letter of the alphabet, and answers to different sub-questions are separated by ;.The answer format should be like [[A];[A]].

### Answer:
response:
Let's break down and solve each sub-question according to the provided logic rules and equivalences.

### Sub-question 1: ((p>q)&(p>r))::=::(p>(q|r))

First, we should convert the implication symbols `>` into their equivalent disjunction and negation forms.

- The left side, `(p>q)&(p>r)`, according to rule (10), transforms into `(!p|q)&(!p|r)`.

Now, let's consider the right side, `p>(q|r)`:
- Using rule (10), this transforms into `!p|(q|r)`.

We now need to see if these two expressions are equivalent according to our rules:
- `(!p|q)&(!p|r)` vs. `!p|(q|r)`.

Using distributive laws and properties, let's transform the left side to see if we can obtain the form of the right side:
- `(!p|q)&(!p|r)`
- Applying the distributive law from rule (5), this is equivalent to `!p&(q|!p)&!p&(r|!p)`.
- Simplifying, we get `!p&(q|!p|r)`.
- As `q|!p|r` is logically equivalent to `q|r` because `!p` is already distributed.

However, it's quite clear that `!p&(q|!p)` and `!p|(q|r)` do not directly simplify to equivalent forms according to the provided rules, indicating these are different expressions. Thus, the initial equivalence is not valid according to our basic equivalences.

### Sub-question 2: !(p=q)::=::(p|q)&!(p&q)

Firstly, `!(p=q)` using rules provided equates to `!( (p>q) & (q>p) )` or `!( (!p|q) & (!q|p) )`.
- Using De Morgan's law (Rule 6), this becomes `!(!p|q) | !( !q|p )`, or `p&!q | q&!p`.

Now, consider the right side, `(p|q)&!(p&q)`:
- This part has truth conditions that disallow both `p&q` being true simultaneously but allows for either to individually be true.

Comparing these,
- `p&!q | q&!p` means `p` holds without `q` or `q` holds without `p`.
- `(p|q)&!(p&q)` means either `p` or `q`, but not both.

Thus, these are logically equivalent, correctly reflecting the scenario where neither proposition can imply the other while being true independently.

### Final answer:

[[B];[A]]

### Part 1: (p⇓q)⇓r::=::p⇓(q⇓r)

1. By equivalence (16), \(p⇓q ::=:: !p & !q\).
2. Let's replace the NOR operations with AND operations: \((p⇓q)⇓r ::=:: (!p & !q)⇓r\).
3. Using the equivalence again, this becomes \(!(!p & !q) & !r\).
4. Applying De Morgan's law, we get \(!!p | !!q & !r\).
5. Using equivalence (1) (\(A ::=:: !!A\)), this simplifies further to \(p | q & !r\).

Now, let's evaluate the right-hand side.
1. By the same process, \(q⇓r ::=:: !q & !r\).
2. Thus, \(p⇓(q⇓r) ::=:: !p & !(q⇓r)\).
3. Replacing \(q⇓r\) by its equivalence gives us \(!p & !(!q & !r)\).
4. Applying De Morgan's law, this becomes \(!p & (!q | !!r)\).
5. Simplifying again using equivalence (1), we get \(!p & (!q | r)\).

Therefore, the statement \( (p⇓q)⇓r ::=:: p⇓(q⇓r) \) translates to \(p | q & !r ::=:: !p & (!q | r)\). These two expressions are not logically equivalent. Hence, the equivalence is not valid.

### Part 2: (p⇑q)⇑r::=::p⇑(q⇑r)

1. By equivalence (15), \(p⇑q ::=:: !p | !q\).
2. Thus, \((p⇑q)⇑r ::=:: (!p | !q)⇑r\).
3. By the same equivalence, this becomes \(!!(p | q) ⇑ r\).
4. Using equivalence (1), this simplifies to \((p | q)⇑r\).
5. Replacing with the NAND equivalence again, this becomes \(!(!p | !q) | !r\).
6. Applying De Morgan's law, this simplifies to \(!(!p | !q) | !r\), which further simplifies to \(!(!p | !q) | !r\).

For the right-hand side:
1. \(q⇑r ::=:: !q | !r\).
2. So, \(p⇑(q⇑r) ::=:: !p | !(q⇑r)\).
3. Replacing \(q⇑r\) by its equivalence gives us \(!p | !(!q | !r)\).
4. Applying De Morgan's law, this becomes \(!p | (q & r)\).

Therefore, the statement \((p⇑q)⇑r ::=:: p⇑(q⇑r)\) translates to \((p | q)⇑r ::=:: !p | (q & r)\), or more accurately, \(!(!p | !q) | !r ::=:: !p | (q & r)\). These two expressions are not logically equivalent either. Hence, this equivalence is also not valid.

Since neither of the equivalences is valid, the answers are both negative.

Third person: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou." 
Exactly one of p,q,r is true, and the other two are false.
According to the rules stated, each person's statement should be represented using simple propositions. So, what would the statements of First person, Second person, and Third person be represented as?

response:
To represent each person's statements using the provided logical propositions and adhering to the logical operators defined, we can formulate the statements as follows:

1. The First person’s statement is "Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai." 
   This is logically represented as `!p & q`.

2. The Second person’s statement is "Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou."
   This is logically represented as `!q & p`.

3. The Third person’s statement is "Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou."
   This is logically represented as `!q & !r`.

Given the requirement of translating into a standard format for logical equivalences, as indicated, these statements are captured in logical expression form as:

```
[!p & q; !q & p; !q & !r]
```

Thus, the statements of the first person, second person, and third person, in that order, are represented as:
[[!p & q]; [!q & p]; [!q & !r]].

response:
To derive the solution, we first hold the derived logical expression from the given scenario:

\[ E ::=:: (!p&q&!r) | (p&!q&r) \]

Given that exactly one of \( p \), \( q \), or \( r \) is true and the others are false, we can evaluate each part of \( E \) to determine the truth:

1. **\( !p&q&!r \)** implies \( p \) is false, \( q \) is true, and \( r \) is false. This evaluates to:

   \[
   \text{If } q \text{ is true and } p \text{ and } r \text{ are false, then this condition holds true for} 
   \text{ Professor Wang is from Shanghai.}
   \]

2. **\( p&!q&r \)** implies \( p \) is true, \( q \) is false, and \( r \) is true. This condition is contradictory since only one can be true. Hence, it is false.

needle: In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).

If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Logic Rule:

In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Question:
According to the above rules, what are the paired conjunctive terms of (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r)? How can this expression be denoted?
The answer should be in the format [[paired conjunctive terms:...]; [denoted:...]], with multiple paired conjunctive terms separated by commas.

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem, we first need to understand the principal disjunctive normal form (PDNF) of the given expression (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r). This expression already is in disjunctive normal form (DNF) because it is the disjunction of two basic conjunction terms. The next step is to identify the true assignments that make these conjunctions true and then denote them according to the given rules.

The expression (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r) simplifies to ¬p^r because for the conjunction ¬p^¬q^r to be true, p must be false and r must be true. Similarly, for ¬p^q^r to be true, again p must be false and r must be true. Thus, the simplified expression highlights that p needs to be false and r needs to be true for the overall expression to be true, irrespective of the value of q.

Let's represent the true assignment for ¬p^¬q^r:
- If p is false (binary value = 0), q can be false or true (binary value = 0 or 1), and r must be true (binary value = 1).

The true assignments that satisfy the given expression are:
1. (p = 0, q = 0, r = 1) -> Binary: 001 -> Hexadecimal: 1 -> Denoted as m1.
2. (p = 0, q = 1, r = 1) -> Binary: 011 -> Hexadecimal: 3 -> Denoted as m3.

These correspond to the described paired conjunctive terms in the form of the true assignments given by m1 and m3.

Therefore, the expression (¬p^¬q^r)∨(¬p^q^r) can be denoted by its principal disjunctive normal form (PDNF) as follows:

[[paired conjunctive terms:m1,m3]; [denoted:m1,m3]]

### Answer:
response:
To identify the formula \( (\neg p \wedge \neg q \wedge r) \vee (p \wedge q \wedge r) \) according to the given rules, first, we need to determine the binary assignments for each of these terms.

1. Let's identify the binary assignment for each term:
    - For \( \neg p \wedge \neg q \wedge r \):
        - This is true when \( p \) is 0, \( q \) is 0, and \( r \) is 1, which corresponds to the binary number 001 (in the order: \( p \), \( q \), \( r \)).
        - In hexadecimal, this is 1. Hence, it is denoted as \( m1 \).

    - For \( p \wedge q \wedge r \):
        - This is true when \( p \) is 1, \( q \) is 1, and \( r \) is 1, which corresponds to the binary number 111 (in the order: \( p \), \( q \), \( r \)).
        - In hexadecimal, this is 7. Hence, it is denoted as \( m7 \).

2. The formula thus consists of the terms \( m1 \) and \( m7 \).

3. According to the given rules:
    - If the principal disjunctive normal form of \( A \) includes \( m0 \), then \( A \) is a basic formula. In our case, \( m0 \) is not included.
    - If the indices of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of \( A \) are all even, then \( A \) is an all-even formula. In our case, the indices are 1 and 7, which are both odd.
    - If the indices of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of \( A \) are all odd, then \( A \) is an all-odd formula. In our case, the indices are indeed 1 and 7, which are both odd.

Therefore, the formula \( (\neg p \wedge \neg q \wedge r) \vee (p \wedge q \wedge r) \) is an **all-odd formula**.

The answer is [[E]].

### Question:
Given that formula A contains 4 propositional variables, how many formulas satisfy the conditions of being both a basic form and an all-even form?
The answer is a single number, in the format [[]].

### Answer:
response:
To determine how many formulas satisfy the conditions of being both a basic form and an all-even form given that formula A contains 4 propositional variables, we need to understand the specific conditions for these forms.

1. **Basic Form**: A formula is a basic formula if its principal disjunctive normal form includes \(m_0\). This means there is at least one true assignment which corresponds to 0000 in binary or 0 in hexadecimal (indicating that all variables and their negations are false, which is the assignment \(m_0\)).

2. **All-Even Form**: A formula is an all-even formula if all the paired conjunctive terms included in its principal disjunctive normal form have even indices. For 4 propositional variables, the indices go from 0 to 15 in hexadecimal (binary 0000 to 1111). The even indices in hexadecimal for 4 variables would be 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, A, C, E. That is, the binary representations corresponding to these hexadecimal numbers are:
   - 0 (0000)
   - 2 (0010)
   - 4 (0100)
   - 6 (0110)
   - 8 (1000)
   - A (1010)
   - C (1100)
   - E (1110)

Since a basic form must include \(m_0\) (binary 0000, hexadecimal 0), and for it to also be an all-even form, we must include 0000 and can include any combination of the remaining even indices (2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14).

The question is how many combinations of the remaining 7 even indices (2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14) we can have along with 0. This is simply the number of subsets of a set with 7 elements (including the empty subset, which corresponds to only having \(m_0\)).

The number of subsets of a set with \(n\) elements is \(2^n\). Therefore, for 7 elements, we have \(2^7 = 128\) subsets.

Thus, the answer to the question of how many formulas satisfy the conditions of being both a basic form and an all-even form is:

[[128]]

- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Question:
A research institute needs to select 1-2 members from 3 key researchers A, B, and C to study abroad. Due to work requirements, the selection must satisfy the following conditions:

1. If A goes, then C must go.
2. If B goes, then C cannot go.
3. If C does not go, then either A or B can go.

Let p: A goes
Let q: B goes
Let r: C goes

Based on the given conditions, the formula can be derived as:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q))

The true assignments of this formula are the feasible selection schemes. Through derivation, we get:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q)) ↔ (¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∨ (¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∨ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r)

The formula (¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∨ (¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∨ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) is in principal disjunctive normal form and can be denoted as what? This formula belongs to: (multiple choice)
A. Tautology B. Contradiction C. Basic Form D. All-Even Form E. All-Odd Form F. None of the Above

Answer format: [[denoted expression];[options]]

### Answer:
response:
To solve the given problem, let's break down the logic and the given formula step by step.

Given formula:
(p → r) ∧ (q → ¬r) ∧ (¬r → (p ∨ q))

Derived formula in principal disjunctive normal form:
(¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r) ∨ (¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) ∨ (p ∧ ¬q ∧ r)

We need to determine the true assignments and the corresponding hexadecimal numbers for each term in the derived formula:

1. ¬p ∧ ¬q ∧ r: In terms of truth values, if p, q, and r have respective truth assignments 0, 0, 1 (note that ¬p corresponds to p being False, and r being True), the binary representation is 001, which is 1 in hexadecimal. This term can hence be denoted as m1.
2. ¬p ∧ q ∧ ¬r: With p, q, and r having the truth assignments 0, 1, 0 respectively, the binary representation for ¬p (0), q (1), ¬r (0) results in 010, which corresponds to 2 in hexadecimal. This term is denoted as m2.
3. p ∧ ¬q ∧ r: Finally, if p, q, and r have the assignments 1, 0, 1 respectively, with ¬q (0) and r being true (1), then the binary form 101 equates to 5 in hexadecimal. This term is denoted as m5.

So, the formula in its principal disjunctive form can be expressed as:
m1 ∨ m2 ∨ m5

Given the conditions for categorizing the expressions:
- The formula is neither a tautology nor a contradiction.
- It does not fit the definition for a basic form, all-even form, or all-odd form since it has both even (m2) and odd (m1) subscripts in the disjunction.

Therefore:
The denoted expression and the correct category for this formula are: [[m1 ∨ m2 ∨ m5];[F]]

[[m1 ∨ m2 ∨ m5];[F]]

title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

### Question:
If C1 = ¬p ∨ q ∨ r and C2 = p ∨ ¬r ∨ ¬s, 
then dispel(C1, C2) = ? 
Provide the answer in the format [[]], 
or [[];[];…] if there are multiple answers.

### Answer:
response:
Given C1 = ¬p ∨ q ∨ r and C2 = p ∨ ¬r ∨ ¬s, we need to identify a pair of complementary literals in these clauses to apply the resolution rule.

Here, ¬p in C1 and p in C2 can be identified as complementary literals. Hence, we can apply the resolution rule to these literals, which means we need to derive dispel(C1, C2) by removing ¬p and p from the clauses and combining the rest.

C1 = ¬p ∨ q ∨ r
C2 = p ∨ ¬r ∨ ¬s

By removing ¬p from C1 and p from C2, we get:
q ∨ r and ¬r ∨ ¬s

Combining these results in:
q ∨ ¬s
Therefore, dispel(C1, C2) = q ∨ ¬s

In the requested format, the answer is:

[[q;¬s]]

Regarding (¬p ∨ q)∧(p ∨ q) ∧ (q), 
what are S0, S1, and S2 before starting the resolution algorithm, 
and why is S2 after the first loop iteration? 
Provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]],
where sets are represented using {}, 
and an empty set is denoted by ∅.

### Answer:
response:
Let's break down the problem using the provided logic rule and steps mentioned in the Resolution Algorithm.

Initially, the conjunctive normal form (S) is (¬p ∨ q)∧(p ∨ q) ∧ (q).

1. Initialization: Before starting the resolution algorithm, sets S0 and S2 are empty, and S1 contains all the simple disjunctive clauses in S.

   - S0 = ∅ (empty set)
   - S1 = {¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q}
   - S2 = ∅ (empty set)

Thus, the initial state of the sets is [∅;{¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q};∅].

2. The first loop iteration in the resolution algorithm attempts to resolve clauses in S1 and adds any new results to S2.

- We have three clauses in S1: (¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q), and (q). Any two clauses can potentially be resolved if they contain complementary literals.

- Resolving (¬p ∨ q) and (p ∨ q):
  - L = q, L' = q (but we are targeting ¬p and p),
  - dispel((¬p ∨ q), (p ∨ q)) = q (since ¬p and p cancel out, leaving only q),
  - Since q is already in S1 (and S0 is empty), we do not add q again.

- There is no need to resolve q with the other clauses (q itself), as it doesn't form a literal pair to resolve against the other clauses of interest.

Since no new information is derived that isn’t already in S1 and no implausible condition was found, no new elements were added to S2.

Therefore, S2 remains ∅ after the first loop iteration.

The state of the sets after the first iteration is [∅;{¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q};∅].

Putting it together:

[∅;{¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q};∅]

### Answer:
response:
To determine the output and the number of cycles for the given conjunctive normal form ((¬p ∨ q) ∧ (p ∨ q) ∧ (q)), we will follow the steps outlined in the resolution algorithm.

The initial set of clauses S is:
1. (¬p ∨ q)
2. (p ∨ q)
3. (q)

Let's start the resolution algorithm:

**Initialization:**
- S0 is an empty set.
- S1 contains the clauses from S, so initially S1 = {¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q}.
- S2 is an empty set.

**First iteration:**
1. Resolving S1:
   - Resolving (¬p ∨ q) and (p ∨ q): C1 = ¬p ∨ q, C2 = p ∨ q, C = dispel(C1, C2) = dispel(¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q) = q. This resultant clause is q and it is already in S1, so no new element is added to S2.
   - Resolving (¬p ∨ q) and (q): C1 = ¬p ∨ q, C2 = q, C = dispel(C1, C2) = ¬p. Since ¬p is not in S0 or S1, add ¬p to S2.
   - Resolving (p ∨ q) and (q): C1 = p ∨ q, C2 = q, C = dispel(C1, C2) = p. Since p is not in S0 or S1, add p to S2.
   
   After resolving clauses in S1, S2 = {¬p, p}.

**Second iteration:**
1. Transfer S1 to S0, so S0 = {¬p ∨ q, p ∨ q, q}.
2. S1 = S2, so S1 = {¬p, p}.
3. S2 is cleared, initially being an empty set.
4. Resolving clauses in S1:
   - Resolving (¬p) and (p): C1 = ¬p, C2 = p, C = dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Since dispensing ¬p and p yields a contradiction (0), the algorithm ends here.

**Output**: Since we found 0, we conclude that the input S is "Implausible". As this process found a contradiction by the second iteration, the number of cycles iterated is 2.

**Final Answer**: [[Implausible];[2]]

### Question:
For p∧(p∨q)∧(p∨¬q)∧(q∨¬r)∧(q∨r), 
what are S0, S1, and S2 before the second cycle of the resolution algorithm?
Provide the answers in the format [[];[];[]],
where sets are represented using {}, 
and an empty set is denoted by ∅.

### Answer:
response:
Let's go through the steps of the resolution algorithm according to the provided rule.

Given Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF):
\[ S = p \wedge (p \vee q) \wedge (p \vee \neg q) \wedge (q \vee \neg r) \wedge (q \vee r) \]

1. Initialization:
   - \( S_0 \) is the empty set \( \emptyset \).
   - \( S_1 \) contains all the simple disjunctive clauses in \( S \):
     \[ S_1 = \{p, p \vee q, p \vee \neg q, q \vee \neg r, q \vee r\} \]
   - \( S_2 \) is the empty set \( \emptyset \).

2. Resolve clauses in \( S_0 \) and \( S_1 \):
   - Since \( S_0 \) is empty, no resolution can be done at this step.
   - Move to the next phase to resolve clauses within \( S_1 \).

3. Resolve clauses in \( S_1 \):
   - Check for resolvability among clauses in \( S_1 \):
     - Clauses \( p \vee q \) and \( p \vee \neg q \) can be resolved since they have \( p \) and \( \neg p \) as complements.
       - Calculation: \( \text{dispel}(p \vee q, p \vee \neg q) = p \).
       - Since \( p \) is already in \( S_1 \), it doesn't need to be added to \( S_2 \).
     - Clauses \( q \vee \neg r \) and \( q \vee r \) can be resolved since they have \( q \) and \( \neg q \) as complements.

For (p∨q)∧(p∨¬q)∧(¬p∨r), 
what is the output of the resolution algorithm?
How many cycles will it iterate? 
Please provide the answer in the format [[output];[number]].

### Answer:
response:
To apply the resolution algorithm to \((p \lor q) \land (p \lor \neg q) \land (\neg p \lor r)\), we follow the steps:

**Initialization:**
- \(S0 = \emptyset\)
- \(S1 = \{p \lor q, p \lor \neg q, \neg p \lor r\}\)
- \(S2 = \emptyset\)

**Iteration 1:**

- Resolve clauses in \(S1\):
    - Considering \(C1 = p \lor q\) and \(C2 = p \lor \neg q\):
        - These cannot be resolved directly since they do not contain complementary literals.
    - Considering \(C1 = p \lor q\) and \(C2 = \neg p \lor r\):
        - They can be resolved on \(p\) and \(\neg p\).  
        - \(C = dispel(p \lor q, \neg p \lor r) = q \lor r\)
        - Add \(q \lor r\) to \(S2\).
    - Considering \(C1 = p \lor \neg q\) and \(C2 = \neg p \lor r\):
        - They can be resolved on \(p\) and \(\neg p\).  
        - \(C = dispel(p \lor \neg q, \neg p \lor r) = \neg q \lor r\)
        - Add \(\neg q \lor r\) to \(S2\).

So, after this iteration, we have:
- \(S2 = \{q \lor r, \neg q \lor r\}\)
- Move \(S1\) to \(S0\) and set \(S1 = S2\).

**Iteration 2:**

- Resolve clauses in \(S1\):
    - Considering \(C1 = q \lor r\) and \(C2 = \neg q \lor r\):
        - They can be resolved on \(q\) and \(\neg q\).  
        - \(C = dispel(q \lor r, \neg q \lor r) = r\)
        - Add \(r\) to \(S2\).

So, after this iteration, we have:
- \(S2 = \{r\}\)
- Move \(S1\) to \(S0\) and set \(S1 = S2\).

**Iteration 3:**

- Resolve clauses in \(S1\):
    - Since there is only one clause in \(S1\), it cannot be resolved with any other clause.
    - \(S2\) remains \(\emptyset\).

Since \(S2\) is now empty, the algorithm terminates and outputs "Plausible".

**Final Output:**
- [[Plausible];[3]]

title: Circuit Diagram
rule_content:
In a simple circuit diagram, logical operators "negation", "conjunction", and "disjunction" function similarly.
When there is one input it is recorded as "I", when there is more than 1 all inputs are represented in order as "I1, I2, ......".
If powered, represented as "+"; if not powered, represented as "-".
The output of the circuit diagram is represented as "O". Hence, a circuit diagram can be depicted and described like a truth table.

### Answer:
response:
For a NOT gate, there is only one input, "I", and the output, "O", is the negation of that input. The circuit diagram for a NOT gate, according to the specified format, can be formatted as follows:

```
[[I, O]; ["-", "+"]; ["+", "-"]]
```

This representation means:
- When the input "I" is not powered (represented by "-"), the output "O" is powered (represented by "+").
- When the input "I" is powered (represented by "+"), the output "O" is not powered (represented by "-").

formatted as [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

### Answer:
response:
For an AND gate, the output is "+", or powered, only when all inputs are powered. Here is the representation for a 2-input AND gate following the specified notation:

[[[I1, I2], O]; ["++, +-", "-, --"]]. 

This notation signifies:
- The inputs are I1 and I2, and O is the output.
- The output is "+" (powered) when both inputs are powered ("++").
- The output is "-" (unpowered) in all other cases: when the first input is powered and the second is not ("+-"), when the first input is not powered irrespective of the second ("-+"), and when both inputs are not powered ("--"). 

However, for clarity and accuracy to the question and format, the most precise representation would be:

[[[I1, I2], O]; ["++, +"; "-, -"]]

This correctly reflects that for an AND gate:
- The output O is "+" only when both inputs are "+", signified as "++".
- The output O is "-" for all other combinations of inputs, symbolized as "-" to cover the scenarios where at least one input is "-".

### Answer:
response:
The logical expression ¬(p∧q) can be broken down into:
1. Conjunction (AND) operation between inputs p and q: p∧q
2. Negation (NOT) operation applied to the result of the conjunction.

In the format requested, we will represent p as I1 and q as I2. The output of the internal AND gate will be represented as an intermediate output before applying the NOT operation. Here's how the circuit diagram would look in the specified format:

- For I1 = +, I2 = +, the conjunction operation would render the intermediate output as +, and applying negation would result in - for the final output "O".
- For all other combinations of I1 and I2 (i.e., +, -; -, +; -, -), the conjunction operation would yield - as the intermediate output, and applying negation would result in + for the final output "O".

Therefore, the circuit diagram is:

[[[I1, I2], [Intermediate Output], [Output "O"]]; [[+, +], [-], [-]]; [[+, -], [+, +]]; [[-, +], [+, +]]; [[-, -], [+, +]]]

However, to strictly adhere to the format requested, without showing the intermediate steps explicitly (only final inputs and outputs):

What is the simple circuit diagram corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q)∨(p∧r)?
Please provide the answer in the format [[input, output]; [output when circuit is powered, output when circuit is not powered]; ...].

### Answer:
response:
To represent the logical expression \((p \land q) \lor (p \land r)\) using a circuit diagram format according to the specified rules, we start by identifying the components and their interactions. In this expression, "p", "q", and "r" are the inputs to the logical gates. The expression involves two conjunctions and one disjunction.

In circuit notation, we are going to represent conjunction with "AND", and disjunction with "OR". According to the instructions, we will use "I1, I2, I3" to represent the inputs "p, q, r", respectively. 

Let's build this step by step:
1. We have inputs I1, I2, I3.
2. Perform AND on I1 and I2.
3. Perform AND on I1 and I3.
4. Perform OR on the results of step 2 and step 3.

To describe this in the format requested, we have to consider every possible combination of inputs being powered (+) or not (-) and the corresponding output. But since we are asked for the circuit diagram format rather than a truth table, it will represent a generalized view:

- Input I1 is connected to two AND gates.
- Input I2 is connected to the first AND gate.
- Input I3 is connected to the second AND gate.
- The outputs of both AND gates are connected to the inputs of an OR gate.
- The output O of the OR gate is the final output.

Based on these steps, the description focusing on connection rather than all truth possibilities is:
[[I1 AND I2, AND_gate_output1]; [I1 AND I3, AND_gate_output2]; [AND_gate_output1 OR AND_gate_output2, O]]

However, according to the exact format requested, associating it strictly with the format [[input, output]; [output when powered, output when not powered]] is not strictly applicable here as that pattern seems focused on outputs for individual truth assignments of the inputs, rather than a generalized description of the circuit structure. ### Question:
Assuming a simple circuit diagram 
corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q)∨(¬p∧r), 
with inputs I1 as "+", I2 as "-", and I3 as "+", 
what is the output? 
Please provide the answer in the format [[output]].

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem, we first need to decode the logical expression in terms of the inputs and logical operations described. The logical expression given is (p∧q)∨(¬p∧r), which translates to:

- (I1 ∧ I2) ∨ (¬I1 ∧ I3)

Given that:
- I1 = "+"
- I2 = "-"
- I3 = "+"

Step by step, we can calculate the output:

1. For (I1 ∧ I2):
   - (I1 is "+") and (I2 is "-")
   - This equates to: ("+" ∧ "-") = "-"

2. For (¬I1 ∧ I3):
   - The negation of I1 is "not +", which is "-".
   - So, (¬I1 ∧ I3) is: ("-" ∧ "+") = "-"
   
3. Finally, we combine the two parts with disjunction (∨), which is logical OR:
   - "-" ∨ "-" = "-"

Thus, the output of the circuit diagram given the inputs I1 as "+", I2 as "-", and I3 as "+" is [[-]].

### Question:
Assuming a simple circuit diagram 
corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q)∨(¬p∧(q∨r)), 
with output O as "+", 
what are the corresponding inputs? 
Please provide multiple inputs that satisfy this condition in the format [[];[];…].

### Answer:
response:
To address this question, we need to find the conditions under which the expression \((p \land q) \lor (\neg p \land (q \lor r))\) results in an output "+", which means the expression must evaluate to true (assuming "+" represents true and "-" represents false in this context).

First, let's break down the logical expression:

1. \(p \land q\): This evaluates to "+" if both p and q are "+".
2. \(\neg p \land (q \lor r)\): This requires \(\neg p\) to be "+" (which means p is "-") and \(q \lor r\) to be "+". \(q \lor r\) is "+" if at least one of q or r is "+".

Given the expression \((p \land q) \lor (\neg p \land (q \lor r))\), the overall expression will evaluate to "+" under the following scenarios:

1. \(p \land q\) is "+" (both p and q are "+").
2. \(p \land q\) is "-", but \(\neg p \land (q \lor r)\) is "+" (p is "-", and at least one of q or r must be "+").

Let's summarize the inputs that satisfy the expression and output "+":

1. [p="+", q="+", r="+" or r="-"] since \(p \land q\) is "+" and results in "+" even if r is anything.
2. [p="-", q="+", r="+" or r="-"] since \(\neg p\) is "+" (because p is "-") and \(q \lor r\) is "+" (because q is "+").
3. [p="-", q="-", r="+"] since \(\neg p\) is "+" and \(q \lor r\) is "+" due to r being "+".

Therefore, the inputs that satisfy the condition can be listed as:

[[+,+,+];[+,-,+];[-,+,+];[-,+,-];[-,-,+]]

### Question:
Assuming a simple circuit diagram 
corresponding to the logical expression (p∧q∧¬r)∨(¬p∧q)∨(p∨r), 
with output O as "-", 
what are the corresponding inputs? 
Please provide multiple inputs that satisfy this condition in the format [[];[];…].

### Answer:
response:
To solve the question, we have to consider the given logical expression and the desired output. The expression is (p∧q∧¬r)∨(¬p∧q)∨(p∨r) and we are looking for inputs which would result in the output "-". This means the entire expression must evaluate to false. We will consider each term in the disjunction separately to find when the expression does not hold, indicating when the output is "-".

Let's evaluate each part:

1. (p ∧ q ∧ ¬r): This term is true only when p, q are true and r is false.
2. (¬p ∧ q): True only when p is false and q is true, regardless of r.
3. (p ∨ r): True whenever p or r or both are true.

For the output "O" to be "-", the entire expression must be false, so all three terms must be false. Thus, we need:
1. (p ∧ q ∧ ¬r) false: p false OR q false OR r true.
2. (¬p ∧ q) false: p true OR q false.
3. (p ∨ r) false: p false AND r false.

Combining all conditions:
- For the first term, we can have p false, r true, or q false (or any combination of these, but it's useful to keep it minimal).
- For the second term, p must be true or q false.
- For the third term, both p and r must be false.

Given the third term being false (p and r both false), the only way the second term can be false is if q is false.

Therefore, the following inputs [[p=false, q=false, r=true]], [[p=false, q=false, r=false]], and any other combinations aligning exactly with these conditions will satisfy the requirement such that the expression output is "-".

Given these findings and ensuring adherence to the format:

```
[[false;false;true];[false;false;false]]
```
This format adheres to the instructions, indicating two possible sets of inputs that could result in the specified output state.

question:
In first-order logic, symbolize the following propositions using 0-ary predicates:
(1) Only 2 is a prime number, 4 is a composite number.
(2) If 5 is greater than 4, then 4 is greater than 6.

For (1), define a unary predicate F(x): x is a prime number. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

For (2), define a binary predicate G(x, y): x > y. 
The proposition can be symbolized as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[]].
needle: Implication: Use ⇒

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.
Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
Given the domain of individuals as the set of natural numbers(N),
F(x): x is even,
G(x): x is prime,

Using 0-ary predicates, symbolize the following propositions:
(1) 2 is an even prime number.
(2) If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime.
(3) Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime.
(4) Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime.

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].

### Answer:
response:
Given the context and the logic rule provided, the propositions symbolized using the given notation are as follows:

(1) 2 is an even prime number.
- Since F(x) stands for "x is even" and G(x) stands for "x is prime", 2 having both properties can be directly stated as F(2) & G(2).
- 0-ary predicate format: [F(2) & G(2)]

(2) If 2 is prime, then 4 is not prime.
- This would be G(2) implies the negation of G(4), which is symbolized as G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4).
- 0-ary predicate format: [G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)]

(3) Only 2 is prime, for 6 to be prime.
- This suggests that for 6 to be prime (G(6)), 2 must be the only prime, meaning no other number should be prime except 2.
- Formally in logic, it would be: G(6) implies all other primes are 2, which can be expressed as ∼Ey(y ≠ 2 & G(y)).
- Simplified with focus on 6's primality depending on 2's uniqueness as prime: [G(6) ⇒ (∼G(2) | (∀y(G(y) ⇒ y=2)))].
- However, since we aim for simplicity and directly relate 2 and 6 without introducing additional quantifier y, the relationship can be: [G(2) & G(6)]
- 0-ary predicate format: [G(2) & G(6)]

(4) Unless 6 is prime, 4 is prime.
- The statement "unless 6 is prime" indicates if 6 is not prime (∼G(6)), then 4 is prime (G(4)).
- This is symbolized as ∼G(6) ⇒ G(4).
- 0-ary predicate format: [∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]

Given the constraints to provide the answers in the requested format of a list of 0-ary predicates, the final response would be:

[[F(2) & G(2)]; [G(2) ⇒ ∼G(4)]; [G(2) & G(6)]; [∼G(6) ⇒ G(4)]]

Please note that in the process, the third proposition [G(2) & G(6)] was simplified from its more formal interpretation to meet the 0-ary predicate requirement and the requested format.

1. A non-empty set of entities 𝐸;

### Logic Rule:

4. Each 𝑛-ary predicate symbol 𝑅 in 𝑀 has a relation R𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑅 in 𝐽.

1. Determine the entity set 𝐸;

### Question:
(a) The non-empty set of entities E = natural numbers N.
(b) a′ = 2.
(c) Functions fJ(x, y) = x + y, gJ(x, y) = x * y.
(d) Predicate FJ(x, y) denotes x = y.

Write down the implementation of the following formulas under J:
(1) ∀x∀y∃zF(f(x,y),z)
(2) ∃xF(f(x,y),g(x,z)

Please provide the answer in [[];[]] format.

### Answer:
response:
To solve the problem as per the given rules, we must interpret each formula under the interpretation provided. Let’s break it down for each given formula:

1. The formula \( \forall x\forall y\exists z F(f(x,y),z) \) means that for every pair of numbers (x, y), there is some number z such that function f applied to x and y equals z. Considering the definitions, we can replace the symbols with their corresponding implementations under J:
    - \( f(x, y) \) is replaced with \( x + y \)
    - \( F(x, y) \) is replaced with \( x = y \)

Therefore, the formula under J becomes a statement about natural numbers. Each output of \( f(x, y) \) yields a pair (x + y, z) that satisfies \( x + y = z \) under FJ, where \( x, y, z ∈ N \).

2. The formula \( \exists x F(f(x, y), g(x, z)) \) suggests there exists a number x such that the function f of x and y equals the function g of x and z. Under the transitions provided:
    - \( f(x, y) \) is replaced with \( x + y \)
    - \( g(x, z) \) is replaced with \( x * z \)
    - \( F(x, y) \) is replaced with \( x = y \)

Thus, \( F(f(x,y), g(x,z)) \) turns into a statement about a pair (x + y, x * z) that satisfies \( x + y = x * z \) under FJ, where x, y, z ∈ N.

Placing the findings in the required format, we have:
[
  [1;For every \(x, y ∈ N\), exists \(z ∈ N\) such that \(x + y = z\)], 
  [2;There exists \(x ∈ N\) such that \(x + y = x * z\), for some \(y, z ∈ N\)]
]

needle: Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
- Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
- Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
- Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
- Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.
title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

[2] All products are not qualified.

[4] Some products are unqualified.

Only when S and P are completely identical do they have a relationship.

Do [1] and [3] have a relationship? 
Do [3] and [4] have a relationship?

Please answer in the format of [[A/B];[A/B];[A/B]].

### Answer:
response:
[[B];[A];[B]]

Explanation:
- **[1] and [2]**: The statements contradict each other in terms of the qualification of products, but they do not directly relate under the specified logical relationships since they are both universal but one is affirmative and the other is negated in a way that does not fit precisely as a universal negative (No S are P). Therefore, they don't have a clear * relation as defined, and thus do not have a relationship based on the provided rules.
- **[1] and [3]**: These two statements effectively make the same claim under different wording. "[1] All products are qualified" and "[3] All products are not unqualified" both express that all products are qualified (in the affirmative for [1] and in the negation of non-qualification for [3]). Since they express the same idea, they do have a relationship.
- **[3] and [4]**: These statements do not have a relationship under the provided rules. Proposition [4] suggests that there exists a subset of products that are unqualified, whereas [3] denies that there are any unqualified products. While they might seem to be in contradiction, these do not fit into the * relation or any other specified relationship because they deal with an affirmative universal statement and a particular negative statement concerning the same subjects but opposing predicates.

- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.

    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
    3. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
